title: Tourism in Turkmenistan
text:
<a href="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a> is a country with large potential for an expanded tourism industry. Many of its <a href="Central%20Asia">Central Asia</a>n cities were main points of trade on the <a href="Silk%20Road">Silk Road</a>, linking Eastern and Western civilizations. Many neighboring countries (including <a href="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>, and <a href="Iran">Iran</a>) promote their countries based on their location along the Great Silk Road. Tourism has grown rapidly in recent years. Tourists from abroad are deterred by the restrictive <a href="visa%20policy%20of%20Turkmenistan">visa policy regime</a> with all countries of the world. Tourism is regulated by the <a href="Tourism%20Committee%20of%20Turkmenistan">Tourism Committee of Turkmenistan</a>.
Historical sites.
There are three World Heritage Sites in Turkmenistan.
<a href="Nisa%2C%20Turkmenistan">Nisa</a> (also Parthaunisa) was an ancient city, located near modern-day Bagyr, a neighbourhood in <a href="Ashgabat">Ashgabat</a> 18 km southwest of downtown. Nisa is described by some as one of the first capitals of the <a href="Parthia">Parthia</a>ns. It is traditionally assumed to have been founded by <a href="Arsaces%20I%20of%20Parthia">Arsaces I</a> (reigned c. 250 BC–211 BC), and was reputedly the royal <a href="necropolis">necropolis</a> of the <a href="Arsacid%20Empire">Parthian kings</a>, although it has not been established that the fortress at Nisa was either a royal residence or a mausoleum.
<a href="Merv">Merv</a>, formerly an <a href="Achaemenid">Achaemenid</a> <a href="Satrap">Satrap</a>y of <a href="Margiana">Margiana</a>, and later Alexandria and Antiochia in Margiana, was a major <a href="oasis">oasis</a>-<a href="city">city</a> in <a href="Central%20Asia">Central Asia</a>, on the historical <a href="Silk%20Road">Silk Road</a>, located near today's <a href="Mary%2C%20Turkmenistan">Mary</a>. Several cities have existed on this site, which is significant for the interchange of culture and politics at a site of major strategic value. It is claimed that Merv was briefly <a href="List%20of%20largest%20cities%20throughout%20history">the largest city in the world</a> in the 12th century.
<a href="Konye-Urgench">Konye-Urgench</a> is a <a href="municipality">municipality</a> of about 30,000 inhabitants in north-eastern <a href="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a>, just south out the border with <a href="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>. It is the site of the ancient town of Ürgenç, which contains the unexcavated ruins of the 12th-century capital of <a href="Khwarezm">Khwarezm</a>. Since 2005, the ruins of Old Urgench have been protected by <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> as a <a href="World%20Heritage%20Site">World Heritage Site</a>. ("See" <a href="List%20of%20World%20Heritage%20Sites%20in%20Turkmenistan">List of World Heritage Sites in Turkmenistan</a>)
Resorts and nature tourism.
The <a href="Caspian%20Sea">Caspian Sea</a> coast of Turkmenistan is the site of a number of popular sea resorts, including the <a href="Awaza">Awaza</a> National Resort Zone.
Wildlife areas in the desert and other attractions.
Desert fauna of <a href="Karakum%20Desert">Karakum</a> include many kinds of rare animals. There is a Karakum nature reserve at the flood-land drained by the <a href="Amu%20Darya">Amu Darya</a>.
Near <a href="Derweze">Derweze</a> village in the middle of the Karakum Desert is a <a href="natural%20gas">natural gas</a> deposit. While drilling in 1971, Soviet geologists tapped into a cavern filled with natural gas. The ground beneath the drilling rig collapsed, creating the <a href="Darvaza%20gas%20crater">Darvaza gas crater</a>, a large hole with a diameter of at . To avoid poisonous gas discharge, it was decided the best solution was to burn it off. Geologists had hoped the fire would use all the fuel in a matter of days, but the gas is still burning today. Locals have dubbed the cavern the "Door to Hell".
Accessibility of the country.
Most trips to Turkmenistan begin with arrival at the capital <a href="Ashgabat">Ashgabat</a> or the seaside town <a href="T%C3%BCrkmenba%C5%9Fy%2C%20Turkmenistan">Turkmenbashy</a>. Ashgabat has a modern <a href="Ashgabat%20Airport">international airport</a>, which is the base of <a href="Turkmenistan%20Airlines">Turkmenistan Airlines</a>. The airport is served by <a href="S7%20Airlines">S7 Airlines</a>, <a href="Turkish%20Airlines">Turkish Airlines</a>, <a href="Flydubai">Flydubai</a>, <a href="Belavia">Belavia</a> and <a href="China%20Southern%20Airlines">China Southern Airlines</a> as well as the national carrier, <a href="Turkmenistan%20Airlines">Turkmenistan Airlines</a>. Another five airports in Turkmenistan (Turkmenabat, Dashoguz, Mary, Turkmenbashy, and Kerki) have international status. Because of current restrictions, tickets for domestic flights cannot be booked or purchased more than 14 days prior to departure. 
COVID pandemic.
Due to the <a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> global pandemic, scheduled international flights have been curtailed, and only special charter flights are allowed in and out of the country. Such flights arrive at Turkmenabat, where arriving passengers undergo a 21-day quarantine.
